title: How to Reseat Players in Poker Tournaments

steps.headline: Calculate the number of players remaining in the tourney.
steps.description: For this example, 35 remain of 40 starting players. Table 1 - 10 players, T2 - 9p, T3 - 9p, T4 - 7p.

steps.headline: Determine the capacity of your tables (most poker tables seat eight to ten players).
steps.description: For this example, there are four 10-seat tables

steps.headline: Divide the number of players by the number of tables, integer only, remember the remainder.
steps.description: 35 players divided by 4 tables is 8 with 3 remainder.

steps.headline: The resultant integer is the minimum number of players that should be at any table.
steps.description: The maximum at any table should be that number +1. Based on the numbers, no table should have no more than 9, and should have at least 8 players. Thus, one player must be moved from T1 to T4.

steps.headline: The director should approach the short table, and determine the open spots, and where they relate to the dealer button.
steps.description: The best choice is to choose to fill a space immediately behind the dealer button - the seat currently occupied by the dealer button or one of the two immediately to the right.

steps.headline: After choosing the seat to fill, the director should approach the heavy table and alert the player in the same position to gather his or her chips to move.
Escort the player to the new table, carrying chips to assist, if necessary.
Seat the player in the correct seat, and so long as the player did not split the blinds or move into the dealer button, he may participate in the next hand.
steps.description: If the player split the blinds (moved into the small), he must wait for the button to pass before entering a hand.

steps.headline: The tables are now as balanced as they can be; the next imbalance may only be a hand away.

text: Calculate the number of players remaining in the tourney. For this example, 35 remain of 40 starting players. Table 1 - 10 players, T2 - 9p, T3 - 9p, T4 - 7p. Determine the capacity of your tables (most poker tables seat eight to ten players). For this example, there are four 10-seat tables Divide the number of players by the number of tables, integer only, remember the remainder. 35 players divided by 4 tables is 8 with 3 remainder. The resultant integer is the minimum number of players that should be at any table. The maximum at any table should be that number +1. Based on the numbers, no table should have no more than 9, and should have at least 8 players. Thus, one player must be moved from T1 to T4. The director should approach the short table, and determine the open spots, and where they relate to the dealer button. The best choice is to choose to fill a space immediately behind the dealer button - the seat currently occupied by the dealer button or one of the two immediately to the right. After choosing the seat to fill, the director should approach the heavy table and alert the player in the same position to gather his or her chips to move.  Escort the player to the new table, carrying chips to assist, if necessary.  Seat the player in the correct seat, and so long as the player did not split the blinds or move into the dealer button, he may participate in the next hand. If the player split the blinds (moved into the small), he must wait for the button to pass before entering a hand. The tables are now as balanced as they can be; the next imbalance may only be a hand away.
